title: 2-on-1 WS Dunker, PNR Reject Start
desc: Players get into threes, with two offensive players and one MIG defender. The offence begins from an imaginary screen reject with the other attacker in a weakside dunker position, after the reject its live 2 on 1.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 Around the Arc
desc: Players get into groups of four with two attackers and two defenders, one defender is the MIG defender and there is one on ball defender, there Is one attacker around the arc and one attacker in a weakside dunker spot. The ball handler begins by starting around the arc with a defender trailing them the play turns live when the offence has two feet within the arc.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 Blind Start WS Dunker, TO if Back to Neutral
desc: Players get into groups of four in a 2 on 2 scenario, the ball handler begins with the ball on the back of the defender with one MIG and one weakside dunker, the play is live when the ball is removed from the back of the defender.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 BOB and SOB Game Winner, Gold or Silver Medals, 8 Sec Clock
desc: Players get into groups of four with a 2 on 2 scenario from a baseline out of bounds or a sideline out of bounds, when the ball is passed in the players have 8 seconds to score either a gold silver or bronze medal shot.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 BOB and SOB Game Winner, Gold, Silver or Bronze Medals
desc: Players get into groups of four with a 2 on 2 scenario from a baseline out of bounds or a sideline out of bounds, when the ball is passed in the players have 5 seconds to score either a gold silver or bronze medal shot.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 Chameleon Re-Spacing Intentions
desc: Players get into groups of four, with two attackers and two defenders, the attacking player has three chances to score however has to start from different depths and angles to the basket. The second defender is helping the on-ball defender however will start in the smile. However after kickout passes players need to look to escape the lava as quickly as possible.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 Chameleon with Ghost Cut Intentions
desc: Players get into groups of four, with two attackers and two defenders, the attacking player has three chances to score however has to start from different depths and angles to the basket. The second defender is helping the on-ball defender however will start in the smile. Players are given more points for scoring of a ghost cut.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 Chameleon
desc: Players get into groups of four, with two attackers and two defenders, the attacking player has three chances to score however has to start from different depths and angles to the basket. The second defender is helping the on-ball defender however will start in the smile

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 In and Out Static Start, WS Dunker Spacing Intentions
desc: Players get into groups of four, player start in a static 2 on 2 scenario along the arc with a weakside dunker and MIG, once the on ball defender puts both feet outside the thee point line the play is live. players need to check their spacing and make sure that one defender cannot guard two attackers.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 2-on-2 In and Out Static Start, WS Dunker
desc: Players get into groups of four, player start in a static 2 on 2 scenario along the arc with a weakside dunker and MIG, once the on ball defender puts both feet outside the thee point line the play is live.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 3-on-3 Around the Arc
desc: Players get into groups of six with a 3 on 3 scenario, the ball handler begins by going around the arc with the on-ball defender following behind. After the ball handler goes into the arc the play is live.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 3-on-3 Continuous Floor is Lava
desc: Players get into groups of six, and get into a 3 on 3 scenario, players play live three on three until a score where the possession resets, players cannot remain in the lava and must look to constantly space out.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Dominoes & Shot Selection
title: 3-on-3 Continuous, Clarity on WS Dunker Spacing
desc: Players get into groups of six, and get into a 3 on 3 scenario, players play live three on three until a score where the possession resets, offence must have a weakside dunker in play.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 2-on-2 Score on Either Basket
desc: Players get into groups of four and set up a 2 on 2 scenario, offence can be deceptive and choose to score on either basket available to them.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 2-on-2 Score on Either Basket, One Dribble Per Catch
desc: Players get into groups of four and set up a 2 on 2 scenario, offence can be deceptive and choose to score on either basket available to them. However, per catch players only get one dribble to score

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 2-on-2 Score on Either Basket
desc: Players get into groups of four and set up a 2 on 2 scenario, offence can be deceptive and choose to score on either basket available to them.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 3-on-3 Cross-Court, Can Change Direction After Half-Line
desc: Players get into groups of six and set up in a 3 on 3 scenario, players start at the half, once the players cross the half they can decide to either continue nd score on that basket or change direction and look to score on the other baset.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 3-on-3, Score on Three Baskets, Not Twice in a Row
desc: Players get into groups of six and set up in a 3 on 3 scenario players then neeed to be near three baskets, groups will then play 3 on 3 and randomly choose baskets to play on however players cannot score on the same basket twice in a row.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 5-on-5 Echo Triggers and Call Coverages Intentions
desc: Players get into a 5 on 5 full court scenario, players need to make sure to call offensive intentions and make sure that coverage solutions are also called out to the whole team.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 5-on-5 FC Trips, Target Players and FC Press Intentions
desc: Players get into a 5 on 5 scenario with target player equally divided, players must make sure that target players are calling primary triggers. Defence need to call full court presses per possession.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 5-on-5 Two Trips
desc: Players get into a 5 on 5 scenario and play live for two trips of the full court.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Transition Offense
title: 5-on-5-on-5 FC, Turnover for Incorrect Spacing, Double
desc: Players get into a 5 on 5 scenario and play lie full court, offence get turnovers for bad spacing however are rewarded for completing relay or skip passes.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 1-on-1 Advantage Start, Must Nash
desc: Players get into pairs and get into a 1 on 1 scenario, ball starts on the defences hip when the ball is released then the play is live, offence can only score of nash dribbles.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 1-on-1 Athlete Led, Teach Barkley or Nash to New Teammate
desc: Players pair up with players who don’t understand a the nash or barkely dribble, then mus explain to new players what those terms mean.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 1-on-1 Barkley
desc: Players get into pairs and set up a 1 on 1 scenario, offence begins with an advantage start and must score gold medals, however they must change their dribble into a post up when they get close to the smile.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 1-on-1 Introduce Nash Dribble, Guided Defense
desc: Players get into pairs and set up a 1 on 1 scenario offence are looking to go for a gold medal finish, defence must cut of the attackers near the smile. When offence reach the smile the players must dribble around the defender and go for a gold medal finish

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 1-on-1+1 Continuous Blast Cuts with Facilitator
desc: Players get into groups of three with an 1 on 1 scenario and a passer, offence stays for three reps and are looking to blast cut to the basket however if the option isn’t there players should come up with creative solutions to score

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 2-on-2 Nashing the MIG Intention
desc: Players get into groups of three with one attacker and two defenders, players set up a live scenario on the arc, the offence attacks the rim for a gold finish with the two defenders however are looking to use the Nash dribble on the MIG during the finish.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 2-on-2 Train Start Create Double Gap, Keep Score Intention
desc: Players get into groups of 4 with a 2 on two scenario and begin in a line with the offence and defence in alternating positions in the line. The player at the front of the line will start with the ball and throw the ball out to the arc. From this the extra offensive player needs to space out in a double gap position and then the play is live.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 2-on-2 Train Start, Create Double Gap and 7 Sec Clock
desc: Players get into groups of 4 with a 2 on two scenario and begin in a line with the offence and defence in alternating positions in the line. The player at the front of the line will start with the ball and throw the ball out to the arc. From this the extra offensive player needs to space out in a double gap position and then the play is live. Players now have seven seconds to score.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Solos & Protection Plans
title: 2-on-2 Train Start, Create Double Gap and Play Until Score
desc: Players get into groups of 4 with a 2 on two scenario and begin in a line with the offence and defence in alternating positions in the line. The player at the front of the line will start with the ball and throw the ball out to the arc. From this the extra offensive player needs to space out in a double gap position and then the play is live. players play until a basket is scored however on a change of possession the ball needs to be cleared to the arc.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 1-on-1+1 Get Pitch and Slip vs MIG
desc: Players get into groups of four with one MIG defender, two attackers run a get action from the top of the arc against a guided defence, after this it is live 2 on 1 against the MIG defender.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 1-on-1 Gets Can't Deny, Keep or Pitch & Slip
desc: Players get into groups of three and set up a 2 on 1 scenario, the offence must use the get trigger and can’t deny keep or pitch and slip, players must find creative solutions to play out of the get trigger.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-1 Gets Pitch and Slip, Only Gold Medal
desc: Players get into groups of three and set up a 2 on 1 scenario, the offence must use the get trigger and slip of it. Only gold medal finishes are allowed.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-1 Gets, Deceptive Start into Under and Twist
desc: Players get into groups of three and set up a 2 on 1 scenario, the offence must use the get trigger but the get player must be deceptive in their starts, office should also look into using the twist trigger to create dominoes.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-1 Gets, Introduction to Gets as a Trigger
desc: Players get into groups of three, with two attackers and one defender, the ball handler will pass to a player who is rising from the wing. The player will then hold the ball and hand it back off to the original passer or keep the ball. After the first pass the play is live.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-1 Gets, Seal & One Hand Catch
desc: none

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-2 Get Scripted Twist, Crack Angle Intention
desc: Players get into groups of four and get into a 2 on 2 scenario, the offense has a scripted get start and then the play is live after this scripted start. Players must look to use the twist trigger and make sure they are getting to the correct crack angle.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-2 Get Scripted Twist, Second Ball Thrown In
desc: Players get into groups of four and get into a 2 on 2 scenario, the offense has a scripted get start and then the play is live after this scripted start. Players must look to use the twist trigger and make sure they are getting to the correct crack angle. After the shot the offensive player who didn’t take a shot will then space out to the three point line for a catch and shoot three.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-2 Gets Static Start, Unconstrained
desc: Players get into groups of four and get into a 2 on 2 scenario, the offence must start a get from static positions before commencing live play.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-2 Gets, Scripted Under and Twist to Punish
desc: Players get into groups of four and get into a 2 on 2 scenario, the offence must run a get trigger from any spacing. Defence must go under and then get back into the ball handler and this should create a 2 on 1 scenario

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 2-on-2 C Continuous, Arrive Alone on Gets Intention
desc: Players get into groups of four and get into a 2 on 2 scenario, the offence must run a get trigger from any spacing in the half court. Defence must switch or go under the get. The player running the get trigger is looking to arrive alone or create space so the defender cant steal the ball.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 3-on-3 HC Continuous, Must Run Get
desc: Players get into groups of nine with a 3 on 3 scenario taking place and one team waiting to come on defence. Players on offence must run the get trigger to score, teams are penalised for not running the trigger correctly. If a team scores, they stay on offence and the defence rotates. The game is run until either offence or defence scores.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Gets/ DHOs
title: 3-on-3-on-3 FC with Get Twist Intervention
desc: Players get into three groups of three, with a team in the middle of the court and tow teams on either basket. the team can choose to go either way to start. A get trigger must be run by offence in the possession however with more emphasis on the twist after the get trigger.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1 Guided, Scripted Reject Start
desc: Players get into pairs and set up a 1 on 1 scenario, the defence needs to allow the offence to reject the pick and roll. After this it is a guided 1 on 1 for a gold medal finish.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1 Hostage Dribble Intention, Spot the Difference
desc: Players get into pairs, and set up a 1 on 1 scenario, defence begins in a t pose stance. The offence will go under one of the defenders arm and this will initiate the live play. The offence is looking to keep the defence behind them and keep them hostage before going for a gold medal finish. Players need to focus on how to be patient with the hostage dribble and hokd it for a longer time to increase the advantage.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1 Hostage Dribble Introduction
desc: Players get into pairs, and set up a 1 on 1 scenario, defence begins in a t pose stance. The offence will go under one of the defenders arm and this will initiate the live play. The offence is looking to keep the defence behind them and keep them hostage before going for a gold medal finish.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1+1 PNR Hostage, Out to Space Shot
desc: none

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1+1 PNR Set-Ups with Multiple Connections and Closeout
desc: Players get into groups of six with a 3 on 3 scenario, a pick and roll is created. The other two offensive players work as facilitators and when they show their hands the ball handler needs to make a pass to them, defence is live.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1+1 PNR Set-Ups with Multiple Connections
desc: Players get into groups of six with a 3 on 3 scenario, a pick and roll is created. The other two offensive players work as facilitators and when they show their hands the ball handler needs to make a pass to them, defence is live.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1+1 PNR Set-Ups, No Under Twice
desc: Players get into groups of three and set up a pick and roll scenario. The play is live however defence cannot go under the pick twice.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1+1 Side PNR, Single Tag "Hot" Closeout
desc: Players get into groups of three and set up into a imaginary side pick and roll with a MIG defender and a wing offensive player. The ball handler uses the pick and turns the corner then will throw an overhead pass to the wing who will then play a live 1 on 1 with the defender. Defenders now need to commit to a hot closeout which means they need to take away the opportunity for the offence to shoot.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 1-on-1+1 Side PNR, Single Tag Closeout
desc: Players get into groups of three and set up into a imaginary side pick and roll with a MIG defender and a wing offensive player. The ball handler uses the pick and turns the corner then will throw an overhead pass to the wing who will then play a live 1 on 1 with the defender.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 2-on-2 Hostage or Full Speed Attack
desc: Players need to get into groups of three, players need to set up in a 1 on 2 scenario, the ball handler needs to then either use a hostage dribble to get to a gold medal finish or if the opportunity presents itself go for a full speed attack.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 2-on-2 Angle or Side vs Coaches, Mixed Coverages
desc: Players need to get into groups of 2 and play an angle or side pick and roll against the coaches, who will change their coverage each repetition.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 2-on-2 Wall PNR, Rub in Tandem Start
desc: Players need to get into groups of 4 and set up a 2 on 2 pick and roll scenario, the coaches will constrain the space by adding walls to the play space. The picker needs to focus on slipping to the basket to get an easy gold medal finish.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 2-on-2 Wall PNR, Rub, Intention to Call Coverage
desc: Players need to get into groups of 4 and set up a 2 on 2 pick and roll scenario, the coaches will constrain the space by adding walls to the play space. The picker needs to focus on slipping to the basket to get an easy gold medal finish. Players need to make sure to call their coverages during the setup of the trigger.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 2-on-2+1 Side PNR, Relay and Boomerang with Shorten Pass Intention
desc: Players get into groups of five with a side pick and roll scenario and an extra passer. The ball handler needs to pass ahead to the extra passer, who should be looking to shorten the pass to the roller, the slipping player is looking to play a 1 on 1 against the switch. After this the ball handler is looking for a boomerang pass from the passer to then play a live 1 on 1.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 2-on-2+1 Side PNR, Relay and Boomerang, Crack Angle Intention
desc: Players get into groups of five with a side pick and roll scenario, with a bigger emphasis on the crack angle and how a perfect crack angle can improve the slip dramatically, and an extra passer. The ball handler needs to pass ahead to the extra passer then the slipping player is looking to play a 1 on 1 against the switch. After this the ball handler is looking for a boomerang pass from the passer to then play a live 1 on 1.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 2-on-2+1 Side PNR, Relay and Boomeran
desc: Players get into groups of five with a side pick and roll scenario and an extra passer. The ball handler needs to pass ahead to the extra passer then the slipping player is looking to play a 1 on 1 against the switch. After this the ball handler is looking for a boomerang pass from the passer to then play a live 1 on 1.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 3-on-3 Side and Rub PNR Spacing, Mix in Gets
desc: Players get into groups of six with a three-on-three scenario. Players should change their spacing every repetition, the possession begins from a rub or side pick and roll but players can also look to use the get trigger.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 3-on-3 Side PNR, Introduce the Relay Concept
desc: Players get into groups of six with a three-on-three scenario. Players should change their spacing every repetition, the possession begins from a side pick and roll. Players should be looking to shorten the pass to the ball handler to make the relay pass more effective. The extra offensive player should change spacing each repetition and look to experiment with different triggers like ghost cuts form the corner.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Pick and Roll
title: 5-on-5-on-5 FC, Flow into Side or Rub
desc: none

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 2-on-1, Knowledge About Building Terminology
desc: Players get into fours, with one defender and three attackers. The ball handler will call a mixture of different triggers and run a guided trigger before playing a live 2 on 1

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 2-on-2 Battleship: Get, Blast, Post-Up
desc: Players get into groups of four with a 2 on 2 scenario. The aim of the offence is to score out of a get, a blast cut and a post up to win the game.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 2-on-2 HC Start, Connect for Trigger Intention
desc: Players get into groups of four and set up a 2 on 2 scenario, players on offence must connect with each other to run triggers by calling the trigger names.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 2-on-2 HC Start, Keep Green or Flow into Yellow
desc: Players get into groups of four and set up a 2 on 2 scenario with a weakside dunker and MIG, the offence gets 10 seconds to score a basket from an advantage start.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 2-on-2-on-2 HC Continuous, Hi-5 Start
desc: Players get into pairs. A coach stands behind the ball handler and will put their hand out, the defender will have to go and hi five the shown hand and when this is initiated the play is live and offence can begin.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 2-on-2, 3-on-3 HC, Introduce to Triggers
desc: Coaches set up a live 2 on 2 game at one end of the court with a live 3 on 3 game at the other end and allow target players to experiment with new triggers.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 2-on-3 HC Continuous, Must Say Score
desc: Players need to get into groups of three. Each half of the court needs three groups. Players play live 3 on 3 until a score and new defence comes into play.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 3-on-3 Introduce 'Short' Spacing on Triggers
desc: Players get into groups of 6 and set up a 3 on 3 scenario, offence need to have a weakside dunker spot filled and play a live 3 on 3 with a pick and roll trigger. During the trigger the ball handler should be looking to see weather the slip is open or if they can make a pass to weakside dunker for a gold medal finish.

module: Principles of Play - Offensive: Mixed Principles
title: 3-on-3-on-3 FC with Principles of Play Intentions
desc: Players get into groups of three. With one group beginning in the middle of the floor and one group at either end of the court. The group of three begins in the middle and can choose either end of the court to attack to play a live 3 on 3. The ball is turned over if a principle of play is not carried out.

title: 1-on-1+1 Pick a Side Post-Up
desc: Players get into groups of three, a 1 on 1 post up scenario is created with a passer passing the ball into the post. The post defender will have to get both feet on either side of the offence to trigger the live play, offence get one dribble only.

title: 1-on-1+1 T Post Introduction
desc: Players get into groups of three, with a 1 on 1 post up scenario and a passer. The passer can only pass the ball into the post when it is signalled by the offence and players only have 3 seconds to score a gold medal.

title: 1-on-1+1 T Post vs Front
desc: Players get into groups of three, with a 1 on 1 post up scenario and a passer. The passer can only pass the ball into the post when it is signalled by the offence and players. Defenders have to front the post offensive player and stop the pass going in.

title: 2-on-2 Train into T Post
desc: Players get into groups of four with a 2 on 2 scenario and all players must line up alternating from offence and defence. The ball is then thrown out to the arc and the play is live, one of the offensive players must get into a post up 1 on 1 situation. The ball handler is looking to get the ball into the post for a gold medal score.

title: 1-on-1 Small Advantage Start, -2 Points for Straight Line Finish
desc: Players start side-by-side with the defensive player slightly in front and offensive player dribbling. The defender starts with a hand on the offensive player’s hip and the defender taking their hand away signals the offensive player to attack the basket. The offensive player can either attempt a regular layup or a Nash dribble. If the defender allows a regular layup to be made without recovering they get -1 points. Scoring will grant the offensive player one point. The first player to 4 points wins. The defense therefore aims to force the offense to use a counter and deny a straight-line layup.

title: 2-on-2 Train Start, Extreme Consequences for No Force Weak
desc: Players separate into pairs and start underneath the basket. The player with the ball spins it out to the three-point line and both offensive players run out, trailed by the two defenders. The defenders will aim to aggressively force the offense into a left-hand finish. A successful right-hand layup will grant the 5 points for the offensive team and resets the defensive team’s score to 0. A successful left-hand layup will grant 2 points to the offensive team. The first team to reach 8 points wins.

title: 2-on-2 Train Start, Must Say Score and Extreme Consequences for No Force Weak
desc: Players separate into pairs and start underneath the basket. The player with the ball spins it out to the three-point line and both offensive players run out, trailed by the two defenders. The defenders will aim to aggressively force the offense into a left-hand finish. A successful right-hand layup will grant the 5 points for the offensive team and resets the defensive team’s score to 0. A successful left-hand layup will grant 2 points to the offensive team. The first team to reach 8 points wins. If players fail to say score their team score is reset to 0.

title: 3-on-3 Continuous, Force Weak and WS Dunker Intentions
desc: Players separate into teams of three and play continuous 3-on-3 in the half court. One offensive player must always be positioned in the weak side. Game to 15 points (2s and 3s) with no midrange shots allowed. If the offense score going right the defense rotates out.

title: 3-on-3 Continuous, Immediate Consequence No Force Weak
desc: Players separate into teams of three and play continuous 3-on-3 in the half court. One offensive player must always be positioned in the weak side. Game to 12 points (2s and 3s) with no midrange shots allowed. Anytime the defense is not forcing the offense left they immediately lose 3 points. If the offense score going right the defense rotates out.

title: 1-on-1 Blind Out of Bounds Start, Play Until Defense Secures Ball
desc: Players start out of bounds behind the basket. The offensive player positions themselves behind the defensive player with the ball on their back. When the offensive player moves the ball the pair play 1-on-1 until defense secures the ball.

title: 1-on-1+1 Battle and Jump Shot Start, Defensive Stop Intention
desc: Two players start underneath the basket. Another player will shoot the ball and the pair under the basket will fight for the rebound. The player who does not get the ball must wall up to stop the offensive player from scoring. A successful wall-up to stop the offensive player from scoring, and securing the rebound before it bounces will grant the defense a point. The first player to reach 3 points wins.

title: 1-on-1+1 Battle and Jump Shot Start, Play off Rebound
desc: Two players start underneath the basket. The shooter will wait for them to have a good battle before shooting a midrange pullup. The pair underneath the basket will then fight for the rebound and then play 1-on-1. Players rotate after every rep. The player with the most stops after 3 minutes wins.

title: 1-on-1 MIG Intentions, Stop through Rebound or Contest and Rebound
desc: Players separate into groups of 3. One offensive player starts in the midrange with the ball, and the other in the dunker position. The defensive player starts underneath the basket. The player with the ball can choose to shoot a midrange pullup, leaving the remaining two players to fight for the rebound. The player can also choose to dribble in and attempt to score from outside the restricted area, forcing the defender to commit to the driver to stop the score. The defense gets 1 point for a stop and -1 point for allowing an offensive rebound. The game finishes when the defender reaches 5 points.

title: 1-on-1+1 Hot Closeouts, Blind MIG Start, Run Off Line Intention
desc: Players separate into groups of 3. The passer will start on either block, with the defense starting on the opposite block and offense in the corner. The passer will roll the ball out, take one dribble and then pass to the offense who is lifting up to the wing. The defense must sprint to close out the offense and take the catch and shoot away, aiming to force a drive to the basket. They can do this by either ‘running the offense off the line’ or by ‘flying by’.

title: 1-on-1+1 Hot Closeouts, Blind MIG Start
desc: Players separate into groups of 3. The passer will start on either block, with the defense starting on the opposite block and offense in the corner. The passer will roll the ball out, take one dribble and then pass to the offense who is lifting up to the wing. The defense must sprint to close out the offense and take the catch and shoot away, aiming to force a drive to the basket. If defense allows a made 3 pointer they stay as defense.

title: 2-on-2 Train, Force Weak and Peel Intention
desc: Players separate into groups of 4, starting under the basket. The first offensive player spins the ball to either the left or right slot. The on-ball defender is going to pressure the ball and ‘lock left’. The second offensive player will go to the other slot and must stay there, while the off-ball defender goes to the shrink spot. Players play live 2-on-2. Defense are penalized with 3 push-ups if they allow the offense to score going right. Players alternate playing offense and defense.

title: 2-on-2 Train, Stay or Peel Switch from MIG Intention
desc: Players separate into groups of 4, starting under the basket. The first offensive player spins the ball to the 45. The on-ball defender is going to pressure the ball and ‘lock left’. The second offensive player will go to the corner and must stay there, leaving the off-ball defender as the help defender. Players play live 2-on-2. If the defense is beat on a drive players will yell ‘switch’ and the on-ball defender will peel across to become the help defender. Players alternate playing offense and defense.

title: 3-on-3 Defensive Rotations within Force Weak
desc: Players separate into groups of 6, all starting underneath the basket. The first offensive player spins the ball out to either the left or right 45. The other two offensive players will fill the weak side 45 and corner. The on-ball defender is going to pressure the ball and ‘lock left’. Players play live 3-on-3. If the defense is beat on a drive players will yell ‘switch’ and the on-ball defender will peel across to guard the open man.

module: Principles of Play - Defensive: Disruptive Strategies
title: 2-on-2 BOB and SOB Game Winner, 3 Scores OR Golden Snitch on Inbound TO
desc: Players separate into groups of 4. The ball starts out of bounds and is inbounded into a live 2-on-2 situation where the offense have 7 seconds to score a game-winner. Offense and defense switch after every possession. The first team to make 3 game-winners wins. However, defense wins the game immediately if they can force a turnover off of the inbound pass.

module: Principles of Play - Defensive: Trigger Coverages
title: 3-on-3 HC Continuous, Rub or Side, Defense Off for Poor Coverage
desc: Players separate into teams of 3. Players play continuous 3-on-3 in the half-court, with the third team waiting on the baseline. The team that scores stays on, however, the defense is sent off immediately if they fail to communicate on a switch. First team to 12 points wins.

module: Principles of Play - Defensive: Trigger Coverages
title: 3-on-3 HC Continuous, Rub or Side, Must Switch Outside 3PT Line
desc: Players separate into teams of 3. Players play continuous 3-on-3 in the half-court, with the third team waiting on the baseline. The team that scores stays on. The defense is sent off immediately if they fail to communicate on a screen or fail to switch on a screen set outside the 3 point line. First team to 12 points wins.

module: Principles of Play - Defensive: Trigger Coverages
title: 3-on-3 HC, Ball Pressure and PNR Switch Intentions
desc: Players separate into teams of 3. Players play live 3-on-3 in the half-court. If the defense fails to aggressively switch on a screen and is more than an arm’s distance away from the ball handler the offensive team is granted 2 points. First team to 12 points wins.

module: Principles of Play - Defensive: Trigger Coverages
title: 5-on-5 Three Lives, Not Communicating Coverage
desc: Players separate into teams of 5 and play live 5-on-5. Each team has 3 lives. Teams lose a life by not communicating left or right on a pick and roll, or if they don’t switch aggressively. A team wins by reaching 12 points or if the other team loses all 3 lives.

title: 4-on-3, 3-on-4, 4-on-3 Three Trips, Improve Intentionality
desc: Coaches need 7 players to set up a 4 on 3 scenario. Players play live 4 on 3 until offence scores or defence get a rebound. Then defence changes to offence and plays a 3 on 4 scenario, there are 3 trips in total. Players must make sure however that they are creating dominoes effectively in the 4 on 3 scenario through the use of triggers and correct spacing.

title: 4-on-3, 3-on-4, 4-on-3 Three Trips
desc: none

module: Principles of Play - Defensive: Mixed Principles
title: 2-on-1 Finishing Two Balls, Defensive Stunt Intention
desc: Players get into groups of three with one MIG defender and two attackers. Players can only score gold medals and both have to attack the basket, this can be at the same or slightly staggered times.

module: Principles of Play - Defensive: Mixed Principles
title: 4-on-4 HC Defensive Shutdown
desc: Players get into multiple groups of four, players will play a live 4 on 4 scenarios, if defence gets a stop they stay on defence until they are scored on. Offence will rotate every time the previous group miss a shot or there is a defensive rebound. If offence score, they become defence.

title: Debriefs, Huddles, and Meeting: Debrief Example Finishing
desc: Here players should be challenged by explaining to the group certain key words or triggers that they have learnt in the practice and be further questioned on it to deepen their understanding

title: All Access Practice 1
desc: Coaches will get an on-court demonstration as the team’s first defensive responsibilities are taught and practiced. Transition offense is emphasized along with different small-sided games and task constraints to develop triggers to be used in half-court offense.

title: none
desc: none

title: All Access Practice 3
desc: This video shows how Alex delivers vitamins segments (player development) with his College Prep team. The practice starts with Alex introducing guided defense to his players for the first time in the season. All player development concepts are closely tied to the game principles which are shown in the full length team practices.

title: All Access Practice 4
desc: The warm-up starts with guided defense used to shape various dribbling and finishing solutions out of a skate dribble. This progresses to a full-court 1-on-2 activity, featuring the PG push which is a key part of the team’s transition offense principles.

title: All Access Practice 5
desc: For this practice, Alex is not mic’d up as coaches learn how music and arena sounds play a key part in his practices! The practice begins showing some of the differential learning shooting used by the College Prep team.

title: All Access Practice 6
desc: The practice begins with some two ball 2-on-2 out of the team’s commonly used Pick and Roll spacings. Alex shows how the same coverage solutions vs switching can be used to equal devastating effect vs the show coverage. The importance of shortening the pass to be available for the relay pass into the roller is consistently emphasized.

title: none
desc: none

title: All Access Practice 9 (Jog Through Bob & Sob)
desc: Practice 9 is a jog through for the team to go through their SOB and BOB plays. This is an example of a low stress practice. Attention to detail is emphasized within a ‘hard-first’ learning environment as Alex deliberately challenges the players through mixing SOBs and BOBs with different calls.

title: none
desc: none

title: Full Game Example
desc: none

title: Team Scrimmage
desc: The bonus bundle includes one inter-squad scrimmage, which took place immediately after the ninth practice session (included in the main video bundle). Alex is mic’d up for this inter-squad scrimmage, where many of the concepts are coherently transferred from the practices over into the scrimmage. Annotated text is added onto the scrimmage to help coaches recognize the offensive triggers being used.

title: Team Scrimmage Video Session
desc: Listen into Alex as he runs a video session with his team, reviewing some key themes (rate limiters) which emerged from the team scrimmage.

title: Coaches Meeting Aims and Principles of Play
desc: Alex opens with setting the stage for the camp starting with having coaches reflect in pairs what skill is. Then he discusses what the traditional view of skill is followed by a more contemporary viewpoint.

title: Coaches Meeting Feedback
desc: Alex here discusses the 3 key aims for the coaches to have in the camp throughout the week: transformational coaching, increase interactions and contribute new ideas for italian basketball. From there he begins outlining how principles of play will be embedded throughout the camp.

title: Coaches Meeting Manipulating Constraints
desc: In this video Alex talks about how manipulating constraints will serve as the coaching methodology during camp

title: Coaches Meeting Optimal Challenge Point
desc: Critical to engaging and developing skill in the athletes involves finding the optimal challenge point. Here Alex discusses how finding and adapting to the players in front of them is vital as well as shows potential activities that might be used via video.

title: Coaches Meeting Summary and Preview
desc: When it comes to feedback Alex encourages the coaches to think of themselves as designers versus instructors. To do so he emphasizes specificity, questions, and positivity.

title: Coaches Meeting What is Skill?
desc: In this concluding video Alex wraps up the meeting with summarizes what he has covered and previews the upcoming film session and on court activities.

title: Video Presentation Blast Cut
desc: Alex introduces dominoes to the campers with a video and has them reflect on what dominoes might be in a basketball context. Before giving a definition and having the campers discuss what qualities make a dominoes sequence successful.

title: Video Presentation Dominoes Definition
desc: In this video the principles underpinning dominoes such as zero seconds with tasking the players to analyze differences between clips; leading to discussion around treating the floor as lava.

title: Video Presentation Dominoes Ghost Cut & Gold Medal
desc: Concluding the film session on dominoes, Alex shows clips emphasizing using a ghost cut on the weak side to end dominoes before ending the session asking the group what shots ended a dominoes sequence; layups and 3 pointers.

title: Video Presentation Dominoes Voiceover
desc: This video is a voiceover version of the video the campers were shown with the same reflective tasks

title: Video Presentation Dominoes Zero Seconds & Floor is Lava
desc: Alex starts the day 2 presentation by having campers discuss the definition of dominoes as well as the 3 key concepts that underpin it. Then he moves into triggers which starts dominoes in the half court if the offense is unable to create dominoes in transition.

title: Video Presentation Recep & Trigger Intro
desc: A cut from a double gap also known as a blast cut is introduced and Alex previews the day on court.

title: How to Use Coaching Clinics
desc: none

title: Player and Team Development Through a CLA
desc: Alex begins by addressing the misconception that team and player development are separate fields. He emphasizes the need for player development to integrate within a team’s principles of play. With this clinic series being a complete introduction to a CLA for the participating coaches, Alex starts with the warm-up. He shows various activities that could be used to start practice such as pac-man and chain tag.

title: Ball Handling and Agility Through CLA Tag Games
desc: Alex shows how team tag can be used as an alternative to traditional drills. CLA informed tag games serve as a great alternative to a dynamic warm-up, while also eliminating the need for one-on-zero dribbling and cone drills. Agility is best developed through decision-making and evading opponents, not through static drills devoid of perception-action. Alex also shows how constraints can be used to improve co-design.

title: Player Decision-Making and Feedback
desc: Alex introduces the popular “floor is lava” constraint, while showing how important it is for coaches to officiate constraints when a CLA is being used. He also talks about feedback, and more specifically how coaches should aim to avoid redundant feedback like “good job” and focus on meaningful, context-specific comments. The concept of a ‘covert check’ is also introduced in addition to player-led timeouts.

title: Spacing
desc: Spacing is the foundation of any offense. Alex shows how Transforming ideas can be used to develop optimal spacing, regardless of the offense you run. This is weaved into converting advantages, with some experimentation using varied dynamics starts. These are useful for disorganizing players and seeing if they can identify more optimal spacing templates from a chaotic start.

title: Stay Alive 1-on-1
desc: In stay alive, players are paired up and assigned into small, designated spaces (e.g., half-circle or other specific areas) to play 1-on-1 with various constraints. In the base version of stay alive, players must keep their dribble alive for five seconds.

title: Navigating Pressure and Transition with Stay Alive
desc: Alex shows how constraints can be manipulated by playing Stay Alive in a 2-on-2, before advancing the ball and flowing into principles of play. This also morphes into a foundational principle of play at Transforming: dominoes or neutral.

title: 3-on-3 to 4-on-4: Introducing Triggers and Transition Play
desc: none

title: 2-on-2 Activities for Streamlined Player Development
desc: Players start in varied positions and work on initiating a trigger (get or pick and roll) to create dominoes. The court space is reduced to increase the challenge. Alex revisits the importance of cracks, while also talking about new behaviours which are emerging (e.g. conceding dominoes too easily in transition defense).

module: Iceland: Peel Switching and Pick and Roll
title: Defensive Rotations and Maintaining Dominoes
desc: Alex shows how a base 4-on-4 SSG with the hi-5 start can be used to develop both dominoes and defensive rotations.

module: Iceland: Peel Switching and Pick and Roll
title: Defensive Rotations and Peel Switching
desc: Alex introduces peel switching. Peel switching from the weak side MIG is shown as a way to get back to neutral after conceding dominoes. The MIG (most important guy/girl) helps on drives and yells “switch” to initiate the peel rotation.

module: Iceland: Peel Switching and Pick and Roll
title: Pick and Roll Decision-Making
desc: Alex sets up “Point of Pick” 2-on-2. Players start at the location of the pick, with constraints limiting play to between the lane lines and a five-second shot clock (as with Wall PNR 2-on-2). Alex talks about the importance of offense (e.g. screening angle, fast rolls and slips), which needs to be done before even getting to defensive coverages.

module: Iceland: Peel Switching and Pick and Roll
title: Screening Angles and Pick and Roll Decisions
desc: Alex changes constraints to flow into Wall 2-on-2 PNR. Now with better intentions of PNR offense, the defense can begin to be shaped.

module: Iceland: Peel Switching and Pick and Roll
title: Using Constraints in Pick and Roll
desc: Alex shows how you can simplify further to improve slips and pocket passes. He introduces the key pick and roll spacings: • PNR Spacings: • Side: Ball on the 45 with a two side ahead • Rub: Middle pick and roll with a two side behind and single side ahead • Clear: Empty pick and roll with a three side ahead • Angle: Step up pick from the corner, three side behind

module: Iceland: Peel Switching and Pick and Roll
title: Pick and Roll Coverages
desc: A continuous 3-on-3 is used, with picks used to create advantages followed by a coverage solution to punish the coverage: Any defensive coverage is allowed, and if the defense gets under the roller (neutral), they gain possession.

module: Iceland: Peel Switching and Pick and Roll
title: Pick and Roll Offense and Defense
desc: Alex talks about the importance of aggressive switching in the pick and roll, with ‘right’ or ‘left’ used as the coverage call for switching. Defensively, an emphasis is placed on creating collisions between the on-ball defender and the picker to neutralize the offense.

title: Implementing Offensive Principles Through Constraints
desc: Alex starts with a 5-on-5 half-court game with three offensive triggers (pick-and-roll, off-ball screens, and gets) to create an advantage. A seven-second shot clock is introduced to encourage quick decision-making and sharpen intentions. The “must say score” constraint is also explained so that players develop the intention to always keep score within their SSGs.

title: The "One Opportunity" Constraint
desc: Players continue in their 3-on-3 and 2-on-2 SSGs, but with one opportunity to create an advantage using a trigger (pick-and-roll, off-ball screen, or get). If no advantage is created immediately, it results in a turnover. The defense are trained to officiate the constraints to avoid an over-reliance on the coach. The defense are empowered to call out “turnover” if the offense fails to create an advantage from the trigger.

title: Gets and 2-on-1
desc: In groups of three or four, Alex introduces a 2-on-1 SSG to sharpen up the coverage solutions. The offensive players run the “get” from various positions on the perimeter, trying to get one foot inside the three-point line. Only one pass is allowed after the get, and scoring can only occur within the smile (a gold medal).

title: Defensive and Offensive Principles in 2-on-2
desc: Alex uses the simple constraint of not allowing a switch on the get, forcing the defense to either go over or under. He emphasizes how players should look to use the entire half-court to run the get in various positions rather than being confined to one part of the court. The defense is shaped by using their leadership voice to call out the coverage.

title: Two Way Coaching in 2-on-2
desc: In this 2-on-2, the defenders must use a different coverage (over, under, switch) for each of three consecutive reps. This should be done in a surprise order. Points are then only awarded for defensive stops, with the first team to four points winning. This improves the defense, subsequently elevating the level of offense in order to create an advantage.

title: Dynamic Starts and Varied Defensive Coverages
desc: A dynamic start is now used to improve representativeness compared to the previous static starts. The offense dribbles to a position on the court (e.g. top, 45, or corner), and defense follows. From here, the players run the get. Other constraints introduced throughout the clinic, such as only gold and silver medals and floor is lava, are continuously reinforced.

title: 5-on-5 with Gets
desc: Teams play 5-on-5 with one trigger. A turnover is called for running the get in a suboptimal location or standing in the lava. The teams play until one team reaches 8 points. By focusing on the “get” as the primary offensive trigger and implementing constraints like the floor is lava, this activity helps players develop dynamic and unpredictable offensive actions while maintaining clear communication and optimal spacing. This approach can be adapted for other offensive triggers like pick and roll or off-ball screens, enhancing players’ overall decision-making and execution in game scenarios.

title: Combining Transition and Half-Court Offense
desc: Alex shows how to incorporate ‘trips.’ The scoring system is exaggerated to place an emphasis on scoring quickly in transition. 5 points are awarded for scoring within 4 seconds of getting the ball, with 10 points for scoring within 5 seconds of being scored on.

title: Dominoes
desc: 4-on-3 bursts are used with a continuous rotation vs two defensive teams. After each rep, the defensive team must run off, and the next defensive team steps in immediately. The offense remains the same for the duration of the activity. Constraints are used to shape dominoes, e.g. must play in zero seconds, floor is lava, etc..

title: Optimal Spacings
desc: Teams start 5-on-4 then transition to 5-on-5. The offense must use various positions to maintain optimal spacing (avoiding the lava). A seven second shot clock is used to encourage decisive intent on offense. Then a paint touch constraint is introduced, where players can only shoot after a paint touch.

title: Constraint-Led Warm-Ups
desc: Alex explains how using the CLA opens up degrees of freedom, allowing players to express more skilful behaviors. This is paired with co-design where the players can interact with the obstacle course in any manner they wish! This approach not only makes warm-ups more engaging, but also significantly contributes to player development.

title: More Warm-Up Ideas
desc: Alex shows how to setup the obstacle tag game, as well as using donor sports such as handball.

title: Scripted and Guided Defense
desc: Alex introduces how scripted and guided defense can be powerful tools in player development. Alex shows how scripted and guided can be used in virtually any context within basketball, for both individual player development and within principles of play.

title: Scripted and Guided Defense Pt, 2
desc: Alex dives deeper into this topic, showing how to use scripted and guided in the context of developing pick and roll coverage solutions.

title: Guided Defense
desc: Guided defense in finishing is used with the “ABC” approach. This is particularly useful in finishing, as shown.

title: Using Dynamic Starts
desc: Alex uses a dynamic start with the zipper action. The offense come off the simulated screen (chair) to receive the ball. If there is no advantage, they flow into the trigger (pick-and-roll).

title: Introducing More Coverages
desc: Alex shares how the exact same approaches can be used vs other defensive coverages. He introduces the show coverage in pick and roll, showing how the CLA can be used to develop coherent coverage solutions for punishing it.

title: Nash Dribble and Protection Plans
desc: Alex introduces the Nash dribble and the term ‘protection plan’ for when players are driving but lose the advantage. Protection plans can easily be developed through guided defense and the CLA.

title: Differential Learning
desc: Alex hits shooting as the last topic in his clinic. He talks about how the CLA and differential learning can be used as alternatives to drills like form and spot shooting.

title: Integrating Theory into Coaching
desc: At the start of this Transforming Live clinic, Alex highlights the importance of integrating theory into coaching. The session begins with a discussion on ecological dynamics. Coaches then split into groups to engage players in shooting activities, designing their own activities with constraints provided by Alex. Afterward, coaches debrief on the activities they designed, with a reflection on the “aliveness" and representativeness of the activities used.

title: Exploring the Constraints-Led Approach (CLA)
desc: Coaches are introduced to the Constraints-Led Approach (CLA) in basketball. Alex provides a summary of what the CLA is and how it can maximize time-on-task and foster the emergence of creative behaviors.

title: Smile 1-on-1
desc: Alex introduces Smile 1-on-1 as a staple Transforming finishing activity, showing all the unique ways constraints can be manipulated within it. The coaches reflect on the increased enjoyment and effectiveness of an activity like Smile 1-on-1 compared to conventional finishing drills.

title: Smile 1-on-1 Part 2
desc: Alex takes a deep dive into Smile 1-on-1 by continuing to show several constraint manipulations. He highlights how different constraints, such as limiting dribbles or changing defensive and offensive start positions, can drastically alter the behaviors that emerge. Alex advocates for individualized constraints that address rate limiters.

title: MIG 1-on-1
desc: In this session, Alex introduces the "MIG" concept, where the help defender is renamed as the Most Important Guy or Girl (MIG). This 1-on-1 involves players driving and finishing from different spots around the half-court. This leads to a good amount of "repetition without repetition.”

title: Jungle Finishing with Pass Option into Around the Arc
desc: Alex shows how there are endless options to change constraints within jungle finishing. By removing one ball and allowing the pass, players now have a passing option. This provides opportunities to re-space and finish off cutting actions.

title: Around the Arc, Amplifying an Affordance
desc: What happens when players do not aim to take advantage of a particular scoring system, or if a coach wants to make an affordance more enticing? Alex provides a practical example of how this can be achieved.

title: 2-on-2 Around the Arc, Varied Spacings
desc: Around the arc is a great start for also developing dominoes and spacing intentions. The natural advantage start is particularly useful for younger players. Instead of always playing out of ‘fixed’ spacings, Alex shows how you can promote more variability within advantage-based small-sided games.

title: A Framework for Youth Offense
desc: Is it really as simple as having shot selection and floor is lava as an entire youth offense? Alex suggests this is the best place to start for many youth coaches.

title: Neutral is a Turnover
desc: One constraint can change everything! The ‘neutralization’ constraint is shown here, where if the defense get back to neutral, an immediate turnover for the offense is called. This promotes more aggressive offensive behaviors to end the dominoes, such as paint touches and attunement to finishing opportunities.

title: Manipulating Constraints within Advantage Starts
desc: Alex provides more ideas for how you can move on from games-based small-sided games, to instead harness the full power of the CLA within advantage-based starts.

title: Building on the Transforming Approach
desc: A key aim of why Transforming exists is to inspire coaches to come up with their own ideas, building on what we share and making our concepts even better! Coach Gennaro Augenti shares how the Transforming approach has impacted his approach to coaching, showing some unique SSG’s and constraints.

title: Transforming Classics
desc: While the aim of a Transforming Live is to show all our ‘best hitters’, in this video Alex shows Curry Shooting followed by Liam Jefferson introducing 2-on-1 shooting. This clinic is particularly interesting to see how Liam had developed an adept usage of the CLA after just one month working with Alex at London Lions.

title: Viewing the World Through an Alternative Lens
desc: Alex outlines the implications for adopting an ecological lens. Compared to the dominant approach to coaching, this is like wearing a new pair of glasses! This is a useful analogy for understanding the paradigm shift now occurring throughout the sporting landscape. At Transforming Live events, we follow a practice-theory-practice methodology to help coaches better connect with our ideas.

title: Reflection on Skill
desc: Alex poses the question of “what is skill” to the attending coaches. Thinking deeply on this question informs us as to why it is important to understand how athletes become skilful, as well as what an effective learning process truly entails.

title: Skill Acquisition Theories
desc: Alex introduces the field of skill acquisition, comparing the dominant information-process approach (IP) to an ecological framework.

title: Q&A into Ecological Dynamics
desc: Alex introduces ecological dynamics as the alternative to cognitive-based theories, such as IP. Several questions with coaches emerge, which Alex unpacks one by one.

title: Making Sense of Basketball Performance
desc: With an ecological framework understood, it is now time for constraints to enter the equation! Constraints allow us to make sense of performance by understanding how certain skills emerge.

title: Newell's Constraints Model
desc: Alex dives into the three types of constraint (individual, task and environment), helping coaches understand the continuous interaction of constraints and how they can be harnessed within the practice environment.

title: Constraint Interactions and Forms of Life
desc: Alex uses the analogy of a DJ mixer. This is followed by a look at sociocultural constraints and ‘forms of life’ and their impact upon basketball performance.

title: Misconceptions of the CLA
desc: As Transforming Basketball has become increasingly known in basketball circles, critiques of an ecological approach have been more vocal in recent times. Alex unpacks some of the most frequented feedback he hears, and what his response would be to these questions.

title: Integrating the CLA into Warm-Ups
desc: Alex shares how the CLA extends to warm-ups, talking about various strategies and approaches used at Transforming Basketball which extend to the warm-up phrase.

title: An Introduction to Differential Learning
desc: Alex outlines differential learning, explaining what it is and how it can be used as a powerful strategy for improving shooting.

title: DL Practical Applications
desc: Alex shares how he has interpreted the research on differential learning, coming up with hundreds of very unique exercises within shooting. Some of these activities are shown in this video.

title: BRADs
desc: Liam shares how we use BRADs at Transforming Basketball, and why they should be integrated into any shooting activities.

title: Co-Design in Shooting
desc: Alex puts the coaches to the test to see what they have learn in the three sessions at Transforming Live! The coaches do a great job designing their own activities using CLA and DL, showing the workshop was successful even within a very short timeframe.

title: Final Debrief
desc: In true Transforming fashion, Transforming Live ends with a de-brief, recapping the coach development and a summary of the ideas shared.

title: What is the Shot Spectrum?
desc: Not all shots are created equal. Placing emphasis on seeking high value shots on offense and low value shots on defense based on points per possession is a key aspect in shaping your team concepts and strategy. Think about only having 24 seconds to navigate an apple store where employees are handing out different iphones from a brand new iphone pro max to a cracked iphone 2, you want to seek the best version you can get during your limited time in the store.

title: Shot Spectrum Clips
desc: To understand the quality of shot taken the term ROB shot can be used. The acronym stands for inRangeOnBalance.

title: Dominoes
desc: Dominoes is the term used for the moment an advantage is created the intention becomes to keep the dominoes falling until a high value shot emerges. There are three rules in dominoes; zero seconds, 1 defender can’t guard 2, and into and out of space. Each rule is shown through clips of successful and unsuccessful examples.

title: Emergency Transition
desc: Like the siege of the castle we have to get back to the castle and pull the drawbridge up to stop the attackers from coming in. This is why the first priority is getting back into the smile to protect the basket this person becomes the goalie. It is crucial if attacked in the smile to wall up and be the second player to jump. Other defenders serve to apply pressure to ball handler locking left forcing them to their weak hand.

title: Shot Transition
desc: On the shot we look to jam up on all four non shooters by getting on the high side of the opponents

title: Peel and Switch
desc: The peel switch is used by a tagger who takes responsibility for an offensive player who has gotten a shoulder past their defender. The tagger calls out BYT and everyone else rotates behind.

title: Measuring success
desc: Instead of measuring success simply by outscoring opponents we use different factors to decide whether we are successful on and off the court.

module: Workshop 21 - Integrating Socio-Cultural Insights for Effective Coaching Practice
title: Tailoring Coaching Strategies to Organizational Needs
desc: * The coaches emphasize the importance of beginning with a high-level overview and a framework that includes principles such as building a shared language, fostering collaboration, and facilitating knowledge exchange among different departments for sports organizations.

module: Workshop 21 - Integrating Socio-Cultural Insights for Effective Coaching Practice
title: Fostering Collaboration Through a Unified Methodology
desc: * In this discussion, the coaches explore rate limiters in professional basketball and other sports organizations, particularly the presence of silos among departments. They emphasize the importance of clearly defined principles of play and a shared methodology that permeates from top-level management down to assistant coaches and support staff. This integrated approach influences recruitment strategies, data analysis, and overall team performance.

module: Workshop 21 - Integrating Socio-Cultural Insights for Effective Coaching Practice
title: Enhancing Performance Through Collaborative Design
desc: * The coaches address key team goals, such as playing quickly in transition or excelling in rebounding, and serves as a foundation for individual development plans (PDPs).

module: Workshop 21 - Integrating Socio-Cultural Insights for Effective Coaching Practice
title: Using a Flexible, Responsive Coaching Approach
desc: * It is crucial to involve players in identifying their own development needs and using that information to guide practice design from the outset. The coaches advocate for a flexible and responsive approach akin to using a map and compass. This method allows for real-time adjustments based on player feedback and observed needs during practice.

module: Workshop 21 - Integrating Socio-Cultural Insights for Effective Coaching Practice
title: Understanding Forms of Life in Coaching
desc: * In this discussion, the coaches delve into the concept of “Forms of Life” and its impact on principles of play within sports teams. They discuss a paper on a rugby league team from a working-class area, where the socio-cultural context shaped their specific approach to the game. The coaches express a desire to understand the community and cultural background of their players to better tailor their principles of play.

module: Workshop 21 - Integrating Socio-Cultural Insights for Effective Coaching Practice
title: Using Forms of Life to Foster Team Cohesion
desc: * The coaches continue with discussing the importance of understanding the socio-cultural context of players to tailor principles of play that align with their natural tendencies and strengths. This involves moving beyond rigid principles and allowing them to evolve based on the players’ unique attributes and experiences.

module: Workshop 21 - Integrating Socio-Cultural Insights for Effective Coaching Practice
title: Reflective Questions for Effective Coaching
desc: * The coaches suggest asking reflective questions to understand the backgrounds and learning frameworks of players. The conversation highlights the challenge of maintaining knowledge sharing and integration within coaching teams, especially when the coaching staff is not always present.
